clean_story:
Space as tiny loops.  Gravity without infinity.


The name loop quantum gravity comes from its core idea—
that space itself is woven from invisible, one-dimensional threads, looped and knotted like a cosmic net.


Most theories treat space as smooth, like a stretched rubber sheet.
Loop quantum gravity says it’s more like a mosaic of pixels—
tiny, indivisible chunks called spin networks.
Zoom in far enough, and even empty space becomes a tangled web of these loops.


Here’s how it works:
When two objects pull on each other with gravity,
they’re not bending an invisible field—they’re rearranging the loops.
Like tugging a fishing net makes the knots shift.


This solves a big problem:
Einstein’s relativity breaks down at the center of black holes,
where math spits out "infinity. "
But loops can’t shrink to zero—
they hit a smallest size, like Lego blocks.
No infinity. No breakdown.


One testable prediction?
Light from distant stars might carry faint graininess—
a fingerprint of space’s pixelated structure.
Telescopes aren’t sharp enough yet to see it.


Three related subjects are
quantum foam structure, 
black hole entropy puzzles, 
and how time emerges from loops.
